issue.title: libcurl 8.9.1 causes abrupt exit due to SIGPIPE
issue.body:
### What is the issue?

transmission-daemon 4.0.6 (38c164933e) began abruptly exiting with process exit code 141 (128 + `SIGPIPE`) after upgrading libcurl to 8.9.1. There is an apparent regression in cURL causing `SIGPIPE` to not be blocked during connection shutdown handling to the same extent as before (see https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/14344).

It's probably fair to say that this is on libcurl, not transmission, but there might be benefit in transmission also being proactively mindful of errant signals.

### Which application of Transmission?

transmission-daemon

### Which version of Transmission?

4.0.6 (38c164933e)

body:
Debugging this further, it appears that libcurl isn't actually causing the `SIGPIPE` that kills the program to be emitted - but in versions <8.9.1 it just happened to suppress it. In our case, we use `cpp-httplib` for creating a small HTTP server for our unit tests. This server emits `SIGPIPE` in its thread in some cases, which was previously handled by libcurl, since those `SIGPIPE`s only happened while curl was performing a request against the server. Now that libcurl doesn't do the ignoring of the server's errors, they're surfacing.

As such, I don't think this is a libcurl issue, but maybe it'd be wise to document this in the release notes since there seem to be other projects which are affected?

libcurl attempts to supress SIGPIPE from within libcurl itself (or rather the dependencies it uses), which it did before and it apparently now fails to do. So yes, I believe it is a libcurl issue.

SIGPIPE is not emitted by the server (at least that won't reach curl), it is instead generally caused when the server has closed the connection and the client (curl) tries to send data on the closed socket.

The `SIGPIPE` doesn't origin from the thread libcurl uses in our application though - at least in our unit tests it origins from the thread of the HTTP server we spawn. Apparently libcurl previously caused the `SIGPIPE`s caused by that thread to also be ignored.

The tests which cause the `SIGPIPE` to be emitted test that our libcurl wrapper correctly rejects invalid HTTPS certificates, so I suppose libcurl terminates the connection upon noticing the wrong HTTPS certificate and the server then causes the `SIGPIPE`.

I'm not sure I follow completely but that's not too important.

The key is that libcurl by default ignores SIGPIPEs during its operation so while libcurl executes it should not receive it - if a SIGPIPE happens in such a circumstance, it is a libcurl bug.

Outside of libcurl's functions, they are restored and happens "normally".

issue.title: [Bug]: libcurl 8.9.1 breaks transmission

repository.name: termux-packages
repository.description: A package build system for Termux.

issue.body:
### Problem description

There's a change in libcurl 8.9.1 that causes transmission-daemon to exit within 30 seconds. The cause is unhandled `SIGPIPE` and the details are already covered here:

https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/14296#issuecomment-2263711275
https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/14344
https://github.com/transmission/transmission/issues/7035

It seems that currently the only way to fix it is to either downgrade libcurl or to revert this commit:

https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/17e6f06ea37136c36d2712b3433ef0d3b118ec0d

There is no mention yet about when to expect a proper fix upstream, so my hope is that you could roll back the Termux libcurl package to 8.9.0 until then. Transmission is literally unusable right now.

### What steps will reproduce the bug?

With libcurl 8.9.1 and transmission 4.0.6, run transmission-daemon in the foreground and wait for approximately 15-30 seconds for it to exit by itself, then echo the return value.

```bash
$ transmission-daemon -f; echo $?
141
```

You should see exit code 141, which is 128 + `SIGPIPE`.

### What is the expected behavior?

Being able to download Linux distro images via torrent.

issue.title: sigpipe: init the struct so that first apply ignores

repository.name: curl
repository.description: A command line tool and library for transferring data with URL syntax, supporting DICT, FILE, FTP, FTPS, GOPHER, GOPHERS, HTTP, HTTPS, IMAP, IMAPS, LDAP, LDAPS, MQTT, POP3, POP3S, RTMP, RTMPS, RTSP, SCP, SFTP, SMB, SMBS, SMTP, SMTPS, TELNET, TFTP, WS and WSS. libcurl offers a myriad of powerful features

issue.body:
Initializes 'no_signal' to TRUE, so that a call to sigpipe_apply() after init ignores the signal (unless CURLOPT_NOSIGNAL) is set.

I have read the existing code multiple times now and I think it gets the initial state reversed this missing to ignore.

Regression from 17e6f06ea37136c36d27

Reported-by: Rasmus Thomsen
Fixes #14344

body: Please test #14390 and see if it changes anything.

@bagder @mkauf Just an FYI: I can verify that a `SIGSEGV` occurs on NonStop when receiving a `SIGPIPE` in sleep mode in the above program. The issue is that `x.sa_handler` cannot be `0x00000000`. Setting it appropriately to `SIG_DFL` does not leak the signal and the program responds appropriately.
I don't understand. This issue is fixed already. Are you talking about the state of things after the fix or not?

> another bugfix release (8.9.2) is probably a good idea...

That train has gone. It would require a serious effort that I don't think this issue is worth.

I'm talking about the state of things before the fix.

I just wanted to point out that libcurl before the fix permanently changed the SIGPIPE signal handler of applications that set `CURLOPT_NOSIGNAL` to 1.
